page_number: 49
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Tractor provisions
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: power lift
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: Stabiliser chain
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Electrical installation
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Hydraulic system of the tractor
- type: TextItem
  text: Before first use
- type: TextItem
  text: 'Working with the machine requires a tractor that at least meets the following
    requirements:'
- type: ListItem
  text: · sufficient carrying and lifting capacity and engine power,  see paragraph
    »Technical specifications« on page 36,
- type: ListItem
  text: · correct type and power lift that can be set well, with linkage frame (optional
    extras) if required for tractors with power lift of Cat. 3 / 4,
- type: ListItem
  text: · ISOBUS communication system and ISOBUS plug attachment or,
- type: ListItem
  text: · assembled ISO control terminal to operate the spreader.
- type: ListItem
  text: · GPS for GEOCONTROL functionality.
- type: TextItem
  text: The tractor must be equipped with a Cat. 2 three point power lift or with
    linkage frame (optional extras) for tractors with power lift of Cat. 3 / 4. Easy
    control of top link and lower link adjustment is important. This system is used
    for several machine settings.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'The tractor must be equipped with stabiliser rods or chains for:'
- type: ListItem
  text: · preventing lateral machine movements and
- type: ListItem
  text: · being able to select the correct position of the machine relative to the
    tractor.
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Lighting
- type: TextItem
  text: A stop contact is required for the lights.
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Control system
- type: TextItem
  text: To operate the spreader, you need a connection for the ISOBUS plug.  See
    chapter »IsoMatch terminal on a NON-ISO tractor« on page 41.
- type: TextItem
  text: The tractor must have a valve to operate the machine accessories.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'This number can increase, depending on the accessories selected:'
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Required hydraulic valves
- type: TableItem
  table_data:
    Function:
      0: ExactLine Left
      1: ExactLine Right
      2: Hydraulic border spreading plate
    Single:
      0: '1'
      1: '1'
      2: '1'
    Double:
      0: ''
      1: ''
      2: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: '49'

page_number: 50
items:
- type: TextItem
  text: Before first use
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Mounting the coupling shaft
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Checking the coupling shaft length
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: '50'
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: The coupling shaft provided is too long for most types of tractors
- type: TextItem
  text: The coupling shaft must be cut to the correct length before connecting it
    to the tractor. A coupling shaft that is too long could lead to serious damage
    to the machine and the tractor.
- type: ListItem
  text:  See the paragraph »Checking the coupling shaft length« below
- type: ListItem
  text:  and the below paragraph »Shortening the coupling shaft«.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'During lifting and lowering of the power lift, the coupling shaft requires
    adequate space for:'
- type: ListItem
  text: · sliding in and out,
- type: ListItem
  text: · sufficient overlap between the profiled tubes when driving the machine in
    the extreme operating angle of the coupling shaft.
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Put the machine on a supporting beam before moving in between the tractor
    and machine
- type: TextItem
  text: This will ensure that the machine cannot drop if the power lift should inadvertently
    be operated while you are between the tractor and machine. Without the support,
    a power lift that drops could wedge you in, resulting in possible serious physical
    injury.
- type: TextItem
  text: The length of the coupling shaft and the shortening thereof must be done after
    the power lift has been connected, but before the coupling shaft has been connected.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Lift the machine with the power lift until the PTO shaft and the machine
    drive axle are level.
- type: TextItem
  text: This is the shortest possible length between the two shafts.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Place the machine on a supporting beam.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Switch the tractor engine off and remove the keys from the ignition.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Engage the parking brake of the tractor.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Disconnect the coupling shaft for it to be two halves.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Mount the loose tractor section of the coupling shaft to the tractor PTO
    shaft.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Attach the loose machine component of the coupling shaft to the drive axle.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Manually align the two coupling shaft halves.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Check the length and adjust it as described below.

page_number: 51
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Shortening the coupling shaft
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: Before first use
- type: TextItem
  text: The profiled tubes must overlap as far as possible, with a minimum of 150
    mm .
- type: TextItem
  text: The profiled tubes must however have at least 25 mm free clearance at the
    outer edges when the tractor PTO shaft and the machine drive axle are level.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Cut off the two profiled tubes to achieve the 25 mm clearance.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Deburr both ends.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Clean the coupling shaft.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Shorten the protection sleeves by the same length.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Slide the coupling shaft halves into each other.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Connect the coupling shaft of the machine and the tractor.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Lift the machine with the power lift in the highest operating position.
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Put the machine on a supporting beam before moving in between the tractor
    and machine
- type: TextItem
  text: This will ensure that the machine cannot drop if the power lift should inadvertently
    be operated while you are between the tractor and machine. Switch also the tractor
    engine off and remove the keys from the ignition. Without the support, a power
    lift that drops could wedge you in, resulting in possible serious physical injury.
- type: TextItem
  text: The maximum operating angle of the coupling shaft is 30 ° when lifted and
    30 ° when lowered.This is the maximum length between the PTO shaft and the machine
    drive axle.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Place the machine on a supporting beam wit the power lift in the highest
    position.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Switch the tractor off and remove the keys from the ignition.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Engage the parking brake of the tractor.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Check if the furthest working angle is less than 30 ° .
- type: ListItem
  text:  Check that the overlap of the profiled tubes is still at least 150 mm.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Remove the tractor section.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Apply grease to the profiled tubes.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Attach the protection sleeves.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Slide the coupling shaft halves into each other.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Mount the coupling shaft to the machine.
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Always mount the check chains of the protection sleeves
- type: TextItem
  text: The check chains prevent the protection sleeves from rotating with the coupling
    shaft. Crop or pieces of clothing can be wound around rotating protection sleeves
    and cause material damage and possibly severe physical injury.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Mount the check chains to both outer edges of the coupling shaft protective
    sleeves.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Mount the other ends of the chains to a fixed point of the tractor and machine
    respectively. System settings
- type: TextItem
  text: '51'

page_number: 52
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Connecting to the tractor
- type: TextItem
  text: Connecting to the tractor
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Neutralise the controls
- type: TextItem
  text: Control devices, e.g. ropes, hoses, etc. for remote actuation of devices such
    as cylinders, shall be guided and positioned in a way they never inadvertently
    release nor block desired movements/actuations! Unintentional movements can lead
    to serious injury.
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Connecting and disconnecting safely
- type: TextItem
  text: 'There are risks of injury involved in connecting and disconnecting the machine.
    Work carefully:'
- type: ListItem
  text: · engage the parking brake of the tractor,
- type: ListItem
  text: · a mobile machine must also be protected from rolling away while being connected,
- type: ListItem
  text: · the machine should only be connected and disconnected from the tractor on
    a firm, dry and flat surface so that the machine would not tilt and/or sink into
    the ground,
- type: ListItem
  text: · ensure no other people are in the immediate vicinity of the tractor or the
    machine,
- type: ListItem
  text: · work in accordance with the guidelines provided in this user's manual
- type: ListItem
  text: · a power lift that conforms with the regulations must be used,
- type: ListItem
  text: · never stand between the tractor and machine while the power lift is operated
    externally while connecting or disconnecting the machine,
- type: ListItem
  text: · the machine must only be connected to the points intended for that purpose,
- type: ListItem
  text: · the machine must only be connected or disconnected while the PTO shaft is
    off,
- type: ListItem
  text: · check the state of the machine in order to ensure that it can safely be
    operated and transported.
- type: TextItem
  text: Connecting or disconnecting the machine in an unsafe manner could lead to
    serious personal injury and damage to the machine.
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Always mount the check chains of the protection sleeves
- type: TextItem
  text: The check chains prevent the protection sleeves from rotating with the coupling
    shaft. Crop or pieces of clothing can be wound around rotating protection sleeves
    and cause material damage and possibly severe physical injury.
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Check the coupling shaft
- type: TextItem
  text: 'Check the following points before the PTO shaft is attached. Has the coupling
    shaft:'
- type: ListItem
  text: · no damage, including the protection sleeves?
- type: ListItem
  text: · are there sufficient lubricants as prescribed?
- type: ListItem
  text: · is the prescribed overlap of the coupling shaft halves and protection sleeves,
    both in transport and in operating position?
- type: ListItem
  text: · Are the protection sleeves attached with chains to a fixed point to guard
    against turning?
- type: TextItem
  text: An unsafe or improperly mounted coupling shaft could lead to serious or deadly
    injury.
- type: TextItem
  text: If the coupling shaft does not comply with the points mentioned above, it
    must be replaced before using the machine.
- type: TextItem
  text: '52'

page_number: 53
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Selecting linkage pin height
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Connecting the machine
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Preparation
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: Stabiliser chain
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Front power lift
- type: TextItem
  text: Connecting to the tractor
- type: TextItem
  text: There is an option of two tension levels, depending on the height of the crop.
    The high hitch points are for normal use, the low hitch points are used if the
    maximum lifting height of the tractor is not sufficient to ensure that the spreading
    height is 75 cm above the crop.
- type: TextItem
  text: The low hitch points are also used when fertilising high crops, which is known
    as top dressing.
- type: TextItem
  text: For further adjustments with top dressing, see
- type: TextItem
  text:  paragraph »Spreading height« on page 95.
- type: TextItem
  text: The space between the spreader and the tractor is limited as far as possible
    in order to keep the centre of gravity as closely to the tractor as possible.
    This promotes stability and the road behaviour of the tractor. As a result the
    coupling shaft, hydraulic hoses and electric plugs must be connected first, followed
    by the power lift.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Move the tractor to the front of the spreader so that the catch hooks of
    the power lift are around 200 mm from the spreader (the maximum distance depends
    on the reach of the coupling shaft; the halves must always overlap each other).
- type: ListItem
  text:  Take the pressure off the hydraulic system of the tractor.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Switch the tractor off, remove the key from the ignition and engage the
    parking brake of the tractor.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Put the lower links of the tractor level with the machine linkage pins.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Compensate for any height difference with the lift rod adjustment of the
    power lift.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Adjust the stabiliser chains to make lateral movement of the lower links
    impossible.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Mount the appropriate ball bearings to the linkage pins and the top.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Secure the linkage pins and top again.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'Only connect the machine to the front power lift if:'
- type: ListItem
  text: · it has sufficient lifting power,
- type: ListItem
  text: · it falls within the same fixing category as the machine,
- type: ListItem
  text: · with linkage frame (optional extras) for tractors with power lift of Cat.
    3 / 4,
- type: ListItem
  text: · the minimum and maximum load of the front and rear weight would not be exceeded,
- type: ListItem
  text: · the tractor has a closed cabin and proper air filters (active carbon filters).
- type: TextItem
  text: '53'

page_number: 54
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Connecting to the tractor
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Coupling the coupling shaft
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: '54'
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: The coupling shaft provided is too long for most types of tractors
- type: TextItem
  text: The coupling shaft must be cut to the correct length before connecting it
    to the tractor. A coupling shaft that is too long could lead to serious damage
    to the machine and the tractor.
- type: ListItem
  text:  See paragraph »Checking the coupling shaft length« on page 50 and
- type: ListItem
  text:  paragraph »Shortening the coupling shaft« on page 51.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Check the PTO shaft and the connector for dirt or damage.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Push in the safety lock on the connector.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Slide the connector on the PTO shaft.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Release the safety lock.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Check if the safety plate latches by moving the connector.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Attach the check chains to both outer edges of the coupling shaft protection
    sleeves.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Mount the other ends of the chains to a fixed point of the tractor, respectively
    the machine.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'During lifting and lowering of the power lift, the coupling shaft requires
    adequate space for:'
- type: ListItem
  text: · sliding in and out,
- type: ListItem
  text: · sufficient overlap between the profiled tubes when driving the machine in
    the extreme operating angle of the coupling shaft.
- type: TextItem
  text: TIP The maximum operating angle of the coupling shaft is 30 ° when lifted
    and 30 ° when lowered.The maximum distance allowed between the PTO shaft of the
    tractor and the driving axle of the machine is reached in this position. A greater
    working angle could damage the coupling shaft.

page_number: 55
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Connecting hydraulic hoses
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: electric plugs
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: Connecting to the tractor
- type: TextItem
  text: In case your machine is equipped with the ExactLine/Hydraulic border spreading
    plate (accessory), you must connect the hydraulic hoses for operation.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Check the hydraulic quick coupling on the tractor for dirt. Clean if necessary.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Remove the hose from the hose coupling support and check the quick coupling
    for dirt. Clean if necessary.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Connect the quick coupling.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Place the hose so that it would not pinch or damage.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Regularly inspect the hydraulic system.
- type: ListItem
  text:  See also paragraph »Checking the hydraulic system« on page 131.
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Connect electric plugs safely
- type: TextItem
  text: Connect the electric plugs correctly. Place the electric plugs and cables
    in such a way that they would not get pinched or damaged. Only use the electric
    stream as intended. Do not use the cigarette lighter.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Check the plugs and the connections on the tractor for dirt. Clean if necessary.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Connect the electric plug(s) for the lights.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Connect the ISOBUS communication plug.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Connect the control box.
- type: ListItem
  text: · by connecting an ISO plug, which has both CAN plugs on the one side of the
    cable, to the back of the control box and the CAN plug on the other side of the
    cable to the connection on the ISOBUS network of the tractor,
- type: ListItem
  text: · Remove the CAN plug of the tractor ECU from the control box if the tractor
    is equipped with a tractor ECU.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Place the cables so that they would not get pinched during working activities.
- type: TextItem
  text: '55'

page_number: 56
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Connecting to the tractor
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Connecting the power lift
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Checking and setting the machine
- type: TextItem
  text: '56'
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Check the decoupling ropes of the quick coupling
- type: TextItem
  text: The decoupling ropes must never be tense and must provide sufficient freedom
    for movement, even with the power lift in the lowest position as it could otherwise
    accidentally disconnect the quick coupling. Accidental disconnection could cause
    damage to the machine and may lead to personal injury.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Start the tractor again.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Reverse carefully so that the catch hooks of the lower links are exactly
    under the ball bearings.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Open the quick coupling of the catch hooks with the release ropes.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Engage the power lift until the ball bearings are correctly located in the
    catch hooks and close the quick coupling.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Check if the catch hooks have locked correctly by lowering the power lift
    carefully.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Turn the top link to the appropriate length and secure if possible.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Open the quick coupling of the catch hook with the release rope.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Let the catch hook fall over the ball bearing at the top and close the quick
    coupling.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Check if the catch hook is correctly secured by pushing and pulling it.
- type: TextItem
  text: Always check the machine after connection and set it horizontally if required.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Lift the spreader until it is lifted from the ground or ramp.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Switch the tractor off, remove the key from the ignition and engage the
    parking brake of the tractor.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Check the locking system of the catch hooks of the lower links and the top
    link.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Make sure that the electric cables and hydraulic hoses do not get jammed.
    Lead them or tie them up in order to prevent dangerous situations. Make sure that
    there is sufficient space for movement when lifting or lowering the machine.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Adjust the machine so that it is level with the lift rod adjustment.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Turn the top link until the machine is standing horizontally.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Lock the top link when that is possible.

page_number: 57
items:
- type: TextItem
  text: To be done before spreading
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Finding the correct data for setting the spreader
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Characteristics of the fertiliser
- type: TextItem
  text: Determine the type and pattern of the granules
- type: TextItem
  text: INDICATION
- type: TextItem
  text: To be done before spreading
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Avoid contact with the fertiliser and other material
- type: TextItem
  text: You will most likely get into contact with the fertiliser and other material
    you may wish to spread while filling, adjusting and testing the spreader. Wear
    protective clothing and gloves, read the safety instructions provided by the supplier
    and follow their directions. Contact with these materials could cause physical
    harm.
- type: TextItem
  text: The data for the correct setting of your spreader can be found in the spreading
    charts in the spreading chart book and the online spreading chart service on the
    website or via the free application (App) for mobile phones.
- type: ListItem
  text:  See also paragraph »Online spreading chart service« on page 61.
- type: TextItem
  text: The spreading charts indicate what type of fertiliser is best suited to achieving
    a good distribution. Correct adjustment depends on the characteristics of the
    fertiliser, not the brand! Determine the characteristics of the fertiliser, therefore,
    and find the spreading chart with similar features. Use the chart, even if the
    brand of the fertiliser differs from the nearest comparable fertiliser!
- type: TextItem
  text: Select the spreading chart based on the characteristics of the fertiliser
    and not on the brand!
- type: TextItem
  text: In order to find the correct spreading chart in the spreading chart book,
    online spreading chart service on the website, or via the free application (App)
    on your mobile phones, you must collect the following physical properties of the
    fertiliser
- type: ListItem
  text: · type and pattern of the granules
- type: ListItem
  text:  see the paragraph below,»Determine the type and pattern of the granules«
- type: ListItem
  text: · distribution (= composition of granules of various sizes),
- type: ListItem
  text:  see paragraph »Determining distribution« on page 59,
- type: ListItem
  text: · similar weight,
- type: ListItem
  text:  See paragraph »Determining similar weight« on page 60.
- type: TextItem
  text: Distribution is the most vital characteristic of the fertiliser when it comes
    to spreading. You can make the first selection from the (online) spreading charts
    based on the distribution. Never use a spreading chart for another type of fertiliser,
    even if the distribution is very similar! You can determine which spreading chart
    compares the best to the fertiliser you are using based on similar weight.
- type: TextItem
  text: Select the type of fertiliser from the spreading chart that is closest to
    the type of fertiliser that you are using.
- type: TextItem
  text: The characteristics of the various types of fertiliser are so far reaching
    that using a spreading chart for another type of fertiliser, even if the distribution
    is the same, could provide a bad spreading pattern and could harm the crop!
- type: TextItem
  text: '57'

page_number: 58
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: To be done before spreading
- type: TextItem
  text: 'Determine the type of fertiliser based on the shape and surface:'
- type: TableItem
  table_data:
    Type:
      0: Granular
      1: ''
      2: mineral
      3: prills
      4: Crystalline
      5: Blend
      6: Pellets
      7: Seed Slug pellets
    Operation:
      0: rough
      1: smooth
      2: ''
      3: ''
      4: ''
      5: ''
      6: ''
      7: ''
    pattern:
      0: roughly round, sometimes slightly  angular, no sharp corners or edges
      1: roughly round, not angular, no  sharp corners or edges
      2: angular, with sharp angles and edg- es
      3: perfectly round, hollow on the in- side, some holes in the surface
      4: oblong, cylindrical, some round pat- terns, hollow on the inside, some  holes
        on the surface
      5: blend of granules with various pat- terns, different from above descrip-
        tions
      6: Pellets of organic material
      7: A seed can vary from species to  species. A seed can have different charac-
        teristics.
    Surface:
      0: rough
      1: relatively smooth
      2: very rough
      3: very smooth
      4: smooth
      5: blend of granules with various  surfaces, different from above de- scriptions
      6: ''
      7: ''

page_number: 59
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Determining distribution
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: To be done before spreading
- type: TextItem
  text: The distribution is the ratio of granules with different diameters. A distribution
    meter comes with every spreader. This meter has 4 sections, with seven parts.
    The seven have different mesh width that divide the fertiliser granules, based
    on their diameters.
- type: TextItem
  text: Distribution of 0-70-30-0 indicates none of the granules has a diameter of
    less than 2.0 mm, 70% have a diameter between 2.0 - 3.3 mm, 30% have a diameter
    between 3.3 - 4.75 mm and none is larger than 4.75 mm.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'You should therefore do the following to determine the distribution of the
    fertiliser with the distribution meter:'
- type: ListItem
  text:  Fill the slot that reads 4.75 mm and close the other openings with the cover.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Close the distribution meter with the cover and keep it on its side.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Shake it for as long as no more smaller granules are falling through the
    sieves.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Turn the distribution meter back up and read the content of each slot. The
    given percentages should add up to 100%. It could be necessary to round the readings
    off with small and round granules.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Repeat the steps above three times and then determine the average distribution.
- type: ListItem
  text: TIP Fill the fraction meter from another part of the hopper in order to obtain
    a good average as the larger granules tend to roll to the outer part of the hopper.
- type: ListItem
  text: TIP Clean the seven parts regularly in order to prevent them from getting
    blocked.
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: 'The last figure indicates how you can read the following distribution: 0-70-30-0'
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: 'Indication with regard to the distribution:'
- type: ListItem
  text: · If the diameter of 10% or more of the fertiliser granules is smaller than
    2.0 mm the fertiliser type would be difficult to spread, especially with large
    working widths. This could result in a less than optimal distribution and could
    damage the crops.
- type: ListItem
  text: · If the diameter of 80 - 100% of the fertiliser granules is between 2.0 and
    4.75 mm, the fertiliser would be good to spread, irrespective of the size of the
    remaining granules.
- type: ListItem
  text: · If the diameter of 20% or more of the fertiliser granules is greater than
    4.75 mm it would be difficult for optimum distribution. This could lead to damage
    to the crops as the granules could make holes in the leaves of the crop.
- type: TextItem
  text: '59'

page_number: 60
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: To be done before spreading
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Determining similar weight
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Finding the correct spreading chart
- type: TextItem
  text: '60'
- type: TextItem
  text: The density is the weight (kg) of 1 litre of fertiliser and it is expressed
    as kg/litre or ton/m3.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'The following material is required to determine the density:'
- type: ListItem
  text: · measuring beaker (supplied),
- type: ListItem
  text: · scale (supplied).
- type: ListItem
  text:  Refer to the scale manual.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'Working method to determine similar weight:'
- type: ListItem
  text:  Hang the empty and dry measuring beaker on the scale.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Press the scale to 0.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Fill the measuring beaker.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Knock the measuring beaker 5 times on firm ground.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Fill up the measuring beaker.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Weigh the fertiliser.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Repeat the steps above three times in order to determine the average weight.
- type: TextItem
  text: Density of at least 1 kg/l is desirable for a good distribution of the fertiliser.
    Lighter types of fertiliser would be more difficult to spread and the maximum
    working width would be limited.
- type: TextItem
  text: On the basis of the data you collected about your fertiliser, for the spreading
    chart of fertiliser with the best comparable properties and desired working width
    in the table of contents of your spreading chart book, or fill in the data through
    the online spreading chart service on the website or via the free application
    (App) for mobile phones.  see paragraph »Online spreading chart service« on the
    following page.
- type: TextItem
  text: You can find the settings for the spreader, based on the application rate
    and the driving speed.
- type: ListItem
  text:  See then paragraph »Setting the spreader« on page 62.
- type: ListItem
  text: TIP the page indicated in the table of index of the spreading chart book indicates
    the settings for the smallest desirable working width. The spreading charts for
    larger working widths are on the pages that follow those.

page_number: 61
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Online spreading chart service
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: AutosetApp
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Telephone App
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: To be done before spreading
- type: TextItem
  text: Information about the settings of the spreader can be found in the
- type: TextItem
  text: 'spreading chart book, but also via the online spreading chart service on
    the website or via the free application for mobile phones with an iOs and/or Android
    operating system. This will also provide information about additional types of
    fertiliser that have been tested recently. You can make use of the online spreading
    chart service as an alternative to the spreading chart book. You must enter the
    characteristics of the fertiliser, your working width, application rate, driving
    speed and the type of fertiliser. You will then receive advice from the website
    for setting your spreader: dosing setting, discharge point, flowrate, vane combination
    and angle of the spreader.'
- type: TextItem
  text: 'Methods for adjusting the spreader can be found at:  chapter »Setting the
    spreader« on page 62.'
- type: TextItem
  text: Also check the advice given on the online spreading chart service. Do a calibration
    test to check the dosing setting. Then check the spreading pattern with a tray
    test.
- type: ListItem
  text:  See paragraph »Spreading pattern check (tray test)« on page 76.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'You can reach the spreading chart service as follows:'
- type: ListItem
  text: ' Go to the website of the Kverneland Group: http://www.Kvernelandspreadingcharts.com.'
- type: ListItem
  text:  The various languages are given at the top of the page.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Start the spreading chart service and complete the details required.
- type: ListItem
  text:  The spreading chart service will then request that you select a product
    with comparable characteristics.
- type: ListItem
  text:  The spreading chart service will then indicate the settings for your spreader.
    Follow the working methods as described in
- type: ListItem
  text:  paragraph »Setting the spreader« on page 62.
- type: TextItem
  text: AutosetApp gives you the option to download these spreading charts to the
    IsoMatch Tellus terminal in order to set the spreader automatically. After choosing
    the desired fertiliser type, the working width, application rate, driving speed,
    dosing and discharge opening are transmitted to the spreader using the AutosetApp.
    The spreader then automatically gets the correct setting. Automatic adjustment
    of the discharge point only applies to GEOSPREAD spreaders. The same data may
    be transmitted to the spreader via the AutosetApp for the other weighing spreader
    models such as Exacta-CL EW and Exacta-TL(X). Except for the discharge opening,
    the spreader then has to be set manually.
- type: TextItem
  text: Using the Kverneland Group spreading charts application, you can easily find
    the right settings for your spreader.
- type: TextItem
  text: The spreading charts application gives you immediate access to the most up-to-date
    test results of fertiliser.
- type: TextItem
  text: In just a few steps, the application will lead you to the correct settings
    for your spreader, any time of the day, wherever you want for almost any type
    of fertiliser.
- type: TextItem
  text: The spreading chart application (App) can be downloaded free of charge through
    the Apple App Store and/or through the Google Play Store.
- type: TextItem
  text: '61'

page_number: 62
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: To be done before spreading
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Setting the spreader
- type: TextItem
  text: '62'
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Avoid contact with the fertiliser and other material
- type: TextItem
  text: You will most likely get into contact with the fertiliser and other material
    you may wish to spread while filling, adjusting and testing the spreader. Wear
    protective clothing and safety gloves, read the safety instructions provided by
    the supplier and follow their directions. Contact with the materials could lead
    to personal injury.
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Be careful that nothing gets jammed
- type: TextItem
  text: 'It is easy for parts to get jammed while adjusting the spreader. Work carefully
    while making adjustments:'
- type: ListItem
  text: · switch the tractor off and remove the keys from the ignition,
- type: ListItem
  text: · engage the parking brake of the tractor,
- type: ListItem
  text: · wait for all machine parts to come to a standstill before you start with
    filling, adjusting or testing,
- type: ListItem
  text: · Never go underneath an elevated, unsecured spreader,
- type: ListItem
  text: · Comply carefully with the instructions.
- type: TextItem
  text: Friction with these materials could cause physical injury.
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Protecting the environment
- type: TextItem
  text: Spreading a too high dose of materials outside of the field edge, especially
    on water surface, creates a heavy burden on the environment. Protect the environment
    by applying a correct application rate in a correct working manner.
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Work with a closed cabin
- type: TextItem
  text: Fertiliser dust can blow indoors through open windows, doors or other openings.
    Moreover, the sound level is higher in an open cabin. It is therefore recommended
    to always work with a closed cabin with active carbon filters in the air inlets.
    Fertiliser dust and a high sound level can cause physical damage.
- type: TextItem
  text: Set the spreader based on the details obtained from the correct spreading
    chart, the desired application rate (kg/ha) and the driving speed (km/h).
- type: TextItem
  text: You can find the methods for determining the correct spreading chart in
- type: ListItem
  text:  the instruction manual of the software.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'The spreading chart page contains information about the fertiliser to which
    this chart relates. Here you will also find the settings you need to perform in
    respect of your spreader:'

page_number: 64
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: To be done before spreading
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Working width
- type: TextItem
  text: The working width must be selected to set the spreader. This could for instance
    be the distance between the sprayer tramlines.
- type: TextItem
  text: In the spreading chart book, via the online spreading chart service on the
    website or via the free application (App) for mobile phones with an iOs and/or
    Android operating system, look for the page that shows the desired working width
    of the fertiliser type with the most similar properties.
- type: TextItem
  text: Various types of fertiliser have a limited maximum working width. This is
    due to their physical qualities whereby they do not spread evenly over large working
    widths. If a working width is not given in the spreading charts, the relevant
    type of fertiliser cannot be spread evenly over that width.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'If you want to spread with a working width not given in the spreading charts,
    use the settings for the working width closest to the selected working width.
    For example: the settings given in the spreading chart for a required working
    width of 25 metres could, for instance, be approximated to 24 metres. Enter the
    actual working width into the control system so that the selected application
    rate is correctly distributed.'
- type: TextItem
  text: 'The working width is adjusted with:'
- type: ListItem
  text: · the correct connection point for the coupling shaft with the PTO speed and
- type: ListItem
  text: · the discharge point.
- type: TextItem
  text: The working width of the spreader is also determined by the chosen connection
    point for the coupling shaft on the central gearbox. Which terminal (turtle or
    hare) you need to use is listed in the (online) spreading chart and depends on
    the desired working width.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Switch the tractor off, remove the key from the ignition and engage the
    parking brake of the tractor.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Detach the coupling shaft from the machine.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Attach the coupling shaft to the correct attachment point.
- type: TextItem
  text: INDICATION
- type: TextItem
  text: INDICATION
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Coupling shaft connection
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: point
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: ListItem
  text: Slow/tortoise connection point
- type: TextItem
  text: '64'

page_number: 65
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Discharge point
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Inclination
- type: TextItem
  text: Angle indicator
- type: PictureItem
  caption: Angle indicator
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Modification during GEOCONTROL use
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: PTO shaft rpm
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: To be done before spreading
- type: TextItem
  text: It is necessary to correctly set the discharge point in order to obtain a
    good spreading pattern and the correct working width. The point at which the granules
    or seeds come onto the spreading disc can be changed by setting the discharge
    point. The position of the discharge point combined with the position of the coupling
    shaft on the central gearbox, the PTO speed and the flowrate determines the spreading
    pattern.
- type: TextItem
  text: The discharge point can be set between positions C to U . The correct settings
    are determined on the basis of the selected application rate and the required
    driving speed. The position that would most likely provide the best spreading
    pattern is given in the third column, Discharge Point , of the spreading chart.
- type: TextItem
  text: Always check the accuracy of the discharge point by conducting spreading pattern
    tests (tray test).
- type: ListItem
  text:  see instructions in paragraph »Spreading pattern check (tray test)« on page
    76.
- type: TextItem
  text: In the (online) spreading chart, look for the Hoek spreader symbol to get
    advice on the angle of your spreader. The spreader is normally in the horizontal
    position. It may be necessary to adjust the spreader's angle with large working
    widths or with top dressing.
- type: TextItem
  text: You can set the correct angle by adjusting the top link. There is an indicator
    on the spreader which displays the angle of the spreader.
- type: ListItem
  text: TIP Set the spreader angle before you fill the hopper. It is easier to adjust
    the top link if the hopper is empty.
- type: TextItem
  text: Check the position again after the hopper has been filled!
- type: TextItem
  text: If the inclination is at 4 o of 8 o , the spreader area slides further behind
    the spreader.
- type: ListItem
  text:  In the machine data screen, increase the length B by 10% or 20% at 4 o or
    8 o .
- type: ListItem
  text:  Please refer to the software instruction manual for the procedure.
- type: TextItem
  text: The (online) spreading chart shows the rpm of the spreading discs as well
    as the rpm of the PTO shaft. The PTO speed is given, as well as the connection
    point to be used for the machine coupling shaft. You have to calculate the speed
    of the spreader discs. The actual RPM of the spreading discs is displayed on the
    control box screen.
- type: TextItem
  text: The PTO shaft rpm often have to be adjusted with border spreading. When using
    the ExactLine and the border spreading plate, you can find the recommended PTO
    shaft rpm and associated spreading disc rpm in the spreading chart book, via the
    online spreading chart service on the website or via the free application (App)
    for mobile phones. Use the connection point shown in the spreading chart.
- type: TextItem
  text: See paragraph »Border spreading« on page 106.
- type: TextItem
  text: '65'

page_number: 66
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: To be done before spreading
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Application rate
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Constant application rate
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: 'The control system can drive the spreader in three different ways:'
- type: ListItem
  text: · distribution that resembles the settings for the preset application rate
    must be determined under changing circumstances through automatic calibration
    and driving speed correction,
- type: ListItem
  text:  see the paragraph below,»Constant application rate«.
- type: TextItem
  text: with similar or lower application rates (< 40 kg/min) the fine application
    kit should be used,
- type: ListItem
  text:  See paragraph »Fine application« on page 67.
- type: ListItem
  text: · with very low application rates on very uneven terrain, preset application
    rates must be checked manually to ensure that the correct dosing setting is being
    distributed, without automatic calibration but with driving speed correction,
- type: ListItem
  text: · under changing circumstances location specific application rate driven by
    an external signal, through automatic calibration and driving speed correction,
- type: ListItem
  text:  See paragraph »Variable, externally driven application rate« on page 72.
- type: TextItem
  text: The control system can spread an equal amount of fertiliser over the entire
    field. In doing so, the control system corrects changes in driving speed, while
    maintaining the option to adjust the application rate manually for over- or underdosing.
- type: TextItem
  text: The control system can search for the correct dosing setting with the preset
    application rate through automatic calibration. The disadvantage is that the application
    rate for the second automatic calibration (= approx. 2 minutes) could differ markedly
    from the selected application rate. It is therefore strongly recommended that
    the starting values be taken from the spreading charts. This can be done in the
    'Curve Calibration' screen. The control system calculates the discharge curve
    from the starting values. The control system corrects the spreader for changing
    circumstances, based on this curve, e.g. as a result of changes in driving speed.
- type: ListItem
  text:  See also paragraph »The ISO control system« on page 30.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'Look for the most comparable fertiliser type and the correct settings for
    the selected working width in the (online) spreading chart:'
- type: ListItem
  text:  Read the setting of the dosing in the Dosing Setting column that goes with
    the selected application rate and driving speed.
- type: ListItem
  text:  The corresponding flowrate is given in the Kg/min column.
- type: ListItem
  text:  The given values are to be entered in the control system.
- type: TextItem
  text: If the selected application rate is not given in the spreading charts, use
    the settings that are the closest to the selected application rate. If the selected
    driving speed is not given, use the settings closest to the selected driving speed.
- type: TextItem
  text: '66'

page_number: 67
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Fine application
- type: TextItem
  text: Fine application handle Normal dosing setting
- type: PictureItem
  caption: Fine application handle Normal dosing setting
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: Fine application handle Fine application setting
- type: PictureItem
  caption: Fine application handle Fine application setting
- type: TextItem
  text: To be done before spreading
- type: TextItem
  text: All three dosing openings normally open uniformly with the selected application
    rate and the corresponding flowrate that you set. With a low application rate
    and/or a low driving speed the dosing openings are only opened a slight bit so
    that very little fertiliser would stream through the dosing openings of the spreader.
    This could easily cause blockage, which would lead to a bad spreading pattern
    and possible damage the crops.
- type: TextItem
  text: We therefore advise that you make use of the fine application if the flowrate
    is less than 40 kg/min .
- type: TextItem
  text: The flowrate with a specific working width, application rate and driving speed
    is given in the fourth column of the spreading chart.
- type: TextItem
  text: If very low application rates (less than 25 kg/ha) are to be distributed,
    e.g. only a few kilograms per hectare, the control system cannot perform automatic
    calibrations. The distributed weight is too small to accurately adjust the application
    rate.
- type: TextItem
  text: Close 2 of the 3 dosing openings to prevent blockages. The remaining opening
    must be further opened as the application rate with the constant flowrate would
    be three times as much.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'The handle to close 2 of the 3 fine dosing openings is located at the outside
    of the spreading disc, above a similar handle for the discharge point. You will
    find the indications on top of the fine application handle for the number of dosing
    openings: 3 open holes for standard dosing and 1 open hole and 2 thick holes for
    fine application.'
- type: ListItem
  text:  Switch the tractor off, remove the key from the ignition and engage the
    parking brake of the tractor.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Pull the hand-grip of the fine application lever out.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Set the fine application handle until the arrow on the hand-grip indicates
    the desired position.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Let go of the hand-grip and check if the fine application handle is locked.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Set the fine application lever on the other spreading disc in the same way
    to the same position.
- type: TextItem
  text: '67'

page_number: 68
items:
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: To be done before spreading
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Dosing setting
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Setting the spreader
- type: TextItem
  text: '68'
- type: TextItem
  text: 'The dosing setting to be set can be:'
- type: ListItem
  text: · Read from the relevant spreading chart when you want to spread at a lower
    application rate using the fine application kit and the symbol of the Fine application
    kit is indicated in the spreading chart. This is indicated by means of 1 open
    hole (dosing opening).
- type: ListItem
  text: · Determine an application rate not given as described in paragraph »Discharge
    point«from page 65.
- type: ListItem
  text: · To be calculated using the relevant spreading chart when you wish to spread
    at a lower application rate with the fine application kit, and the Fine application
    kit symbol is indicated in the spreading chart; it is indicated using 3 open holes
    (dosage opening).
- type: SectionHeaderItem
  text: Calculation
- type: TextItem
  text: As 2 of the 3 dosing openings are closed the flowrate of the remaining dosing
    opening should be three times as much in order to obtain an even application rate.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Read the Dosing Setting, Discharge Point and Flowrate from the spreading
    chart. Calculate the flowrate with the formula given below as required.
- type: TextItem
  text: 'If the selected application rate or driving speed is not indicated in the
    spreading chart the required flowrate can also be calculated as follows:'
- type: TextItem
  text: flowrate required (kg/min) =
- type: TextItem
  text: Working width (m) x Driving speed (km/h) x Application rate (kg/ha)
- type: TextItem
  text: '600'
- type: TextItem
  text: Use the letter given for setting the discharge point in the line of the spreading
    chart that most closely resembling the calculated flowrate.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Multiply the flowrate (given in the Kg/min column or calculated) with a
    factor of 3.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Select the closest flowrate for the whole spreader in the Kg/min column.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Read off the relevant dosing setting or estimate it as closely as possible.
- type: PictureItem
  caption: ''
- type: TextItem
  text: NOTE  Do not use the discharge point indicated there !
- type: PictureItem
  caption: NOTE  Do not use the discharge point indicated there !
- type: ListItem
  text:  Set the given discharge point as described
- type: ListItem
  text:  in paragraph »Discharge point« on page 65.
- type: ListItem
  text:  Enter the dosing setting in the control system and determine the relevant
    flowrate by means of a manual calibration test, as described in the following
    paragraph.
- type: ListItem
  text:  See also the example in paragraph »Constant application rate« on page 66.
